insight.title: Why Your Great-Grandchildren Will Live Like Royalty
insight.subtitle: The secret engine of global progress is simply compounding knowledge.

sections.text: The true wealth of the modern world isn’t measured in gold bars or barrels of oil; it is measured in ideas. An idea—a blueprint for a better microchip, a faster method for growing food, or a new piece of software—is fundamentally different from a physical resource. If I sell you my cow, I no longer have the cow. But if I share my blueprint for a new battery, we both have the information, and we can both build better batteries. This concept, where knowledge can be shared infinitely without being used up, is the most powerful economic force in existence. It allows every successful scientific discovery and technological innovation to become permanent public property, instantly raising the baseline of what humanity can achieve.

Ideas alone, however, don't change the world; they need massive effort and resources to be put into motion. This is where the world of business and finance plays its role as the grand accelerator. Businesses are essentially risk-taking engines, powered by money (capital) that seeks a return. When an inventor has a brilliant idea for a cheap solar panel, finance steps in to fund the factories, distribution networks, and marketing campaigns required to turn that idea into a global product. The incentive for profit acts like gravity, pulling creative minds and massive amounts of funding toward solving problems and increasing efficiency. This continuous pursuit of efficiency is the primary driver of lower prices and better products for everyone.

This combination of science (the ideas) and economics (the incentives) creates what economists call a positive feedback loop, leading to exponential growth. Every generation stands on the shoulders of the last. The engineer building the next great electric car doesn't have to re-invent the wheel, the silicon chip, or the assembly line—those are already established tools, ready to be used as starting blocks. This compounded knowledge means progress isn't a slow, steady march; it constantly speeds up. Today’s smartphone contains technologies that were considered magic 50 years ago, and future generations will benefit from knowledge we haven't even conceived of yet, ensuring that their baseline quality of life will dwarf even the richest standards we currently know.
